reviewText: Whether you're a die-hard baseball fan or not, everyone will find Rumbo a las Grandes Ligas fascinating and enduring.

If you're a fan of the current indie hit Sugar, this look at the Dominican Republic's love affair with baseball is the perfect companion piece. It shows a group of kids who dream of making it all the way, just like David Ortiz and Vladimir Guerrero and a host of others. Visit me at michaelgiltz dot com.

Great documentary, emotional and in many ways inspirational. Will recommend to any parent ,or young baseball player. A lesson not to take things for granted, and to once again remind our selves that hard work pays!!
Good depiction of the struggle the Dominicans have to go thorough in order to make it to the big leagues.
An interesting film for a devout baseball fan and one who enjoys history. Prefer that the subtitles were better done but all and all a decent documentary.

My students enjoyed this film!  It is great for students who are learning Spanish.

I show it every year when I'm doing the chapter on sports.

Similar to Ballplayer: Pelotero [HD] (mostly in Spanish with subtitles) tells stories of youth in Domiinican Republic who aspire to leave the povery of the island for the $ of the United States. Made by a guy from Boston David Ortiz Boston Red Sox (Baseball Card) 2004 Topps #623 is featured as what the boys aspire to become as they go to tryouts, they just do not seem to perform well in front of scouts. 1997 Upper Deck # 271 Vladimir Guerreo -- -- Baseball Card appears and works out hitting, then walks home to his estate. One aspiring player profiled lied about his age so he can not be signed. One player does sign for $25K. Extras include an interview with the director and a piece about the happenings at the stadium there on game day.

Players from the Dominican Republic looking to rise out of poverty and help their families. Features a pair of players in their quest to make it to the majors. Also looks at the origins of such all-stars as David Ortiz and Vladimir Guerrero.

I liked all of the boys and their cheerful determination to make it to the big show and improve life for themselves and their families.  It is sad, however, to realize that very few will succeed.  Their incredible baseball talent won't take them to a college for a degree to fall back on and succeed in a career.  This story reminds me of "Hoop Dreams".  In very few cases will there be a happy ending.

This was a short and entertaining documentary, but was limited in describing the big picture. It could have gone further in defining and explaining the breadth of MLB involvement in the country, the DR's own professional league structure, and given a more well rounded perspective of the country's culture.

This is a great documentary. I really loved it. I used to play baseball in Dominica Republic but stopped playing, which I will regret for ever. If you are a fan of baseball and think those guys make too much money, watch this documentary. Oh man, I loved this. I love baseball with passion. I wish the day I go to heaven I play baseball for ever. The story that made me the saddest, is the one about Rafael Furcal's cousin. That just breaks my heart. Let me not spoil it for you.

Get it and enjoy it.

We've all heard about how many good ballplayers come from the Dominican.  Here's an inside look at what it's like to be a kid with a chance to make it.  It was very real and very interesting.  The stories from Vlad Guerrero and David Ortiz were good, especially Big Papi's hilarious description of what they used in place of a ball for stickball - and how they got it.  I highly recommend this film.
Good
The movie does a good job of telling the story of Dominican baseball from a variety of perspectives.
Found it a little hard to watch.
A look behind the baseball players of the DR.
Very interesting documentary about baseball in the D.R.
Good movie
Good story.
It's a great movie to watch if you love baseball.
A little old, but still good
Great insight on the Dominican culture.
